message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history of scraping his foot on a rusty razor suggest tetanus infection. Wound debridement should be performed to remove any contaminated tissue, and an antitoxin should be administered to neutralize the toxin produced by the bacteria. A booster vaccine can also be given to prevent future infections, but the patient's current symptoms require immediate treatment with wound debridement and antitoxin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest tetanus, which is caused by the toxins produced by Clostridium tetani. Antitoxin should be given to neutralize the toxin, and wound debridement should be done to remove the source of the bacteria. A booster vaccine should also be given to prevent future tetanus infections. Option (D) includes all three options and is therefore the most appropriate treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and wound history suggest the patient may have tetanus, which is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani producing tetanospasmin toxin. Treatment should include wound debridement and antitoxin to neutralize the circulating toxin. A booster vaccine can also be given to prevent future infections, but it will not treat the current infection. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), wound debridement and antitoxin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the history suggest tetanus infection due to the rusty razor injury. Treatment should include wound debridement and antitoxin administration. Booster vaccines can be given after the initial treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Tetanus infection caused by the rusty razor. Treatment with antitoxin and wound debridement should be started as soon as possible to prevent further progression of the infection. A booster vaccine may also be given but it will not treat the current infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest tetanus, a potentially life-threatening infection caused by Clostridium tetani bacteria that produce a neurotoxin. Wound debridement is crucial to reduce bacterial load, and antitoxin is given to neutralize the unbound toxin. A booster vaccine will be given after wound healing, as the patient’s vaccination status is unclear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of a wound, muscle spasms, and rigid abdominal muscles suggest tetanus infection. The dirty appearing wound confirms the suspicion. Treatment includes wound debridement and antitoxin administration, which will neutralize circulating tetanus toxin. A booster vaccine will also be needed after the infection is controlled. However, it is not the immediate treatment for the acute infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest tetanus infection caused by the rusty razor wound. Treatment should begin with wound debridement and administration of tetanus antitoxin to neutralize the tetanus toxin. Booster vaccine is recommended after the patient recovers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe muscle spasms and rigid abdominal muscles suggest the patient is experiencing tetanus, which is caused by toxins produced by Clostridium tetani bacteria found in soil or animal feces. The dirty wound on his right foot is likely the source of the infection. Treatment should include wound debridement to remove any remaining infected tissue and administration of antitoxin. A booster vaccine is not necessary at this time since the patient has not had any recent vaccinations, but it should be administered once he has recovered.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including muscle spasms, suggest the patient has tetanus, which is caused by Clostridium tetani. The wound should be debrided, and antitoxin should be administered to neutralize the toxin. A booster vaccine won’t have an immediate effect on treating the symptoms.
